item.description:
“The Changing Face of Media”
Saturday, March 20, 2010
At the Millyard Museum
10:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m.
FREE Manchester Historic Association members; $10 general public (includes museum admission)
Please RSVP

Digital media is changing the way we consume news. Circulation has plunged at newspapers across America. It is almost impossible to find a local newscast on the radio anymore. The speed of social networks means we don’t look for news – it finds us. Consider:

- If Facebook were a country it would be the world’s fourth largest.
- The No. 2 largest search engine in the world is YouTube.
- Only 14% of people trust advertisements.
- The fastest growing segment on Facebook is 55-65 year-old females.

Ed Brouder will present an entertaining overview of the history of communications with a peek at the future of digital media. Mr. Brouder is a former broadcaster who teaches communications courses at Hesser College in Manchester.
item.how_to_find_us: I will be wearing a name tag.
item.name: "The Changing Face of Media"
